title: Sean Longstaff must ignore Manchester United interest and get back to form - Bruce
text:
Steve Bruce has told Sean Longstaff to worry about his performances on the pitch rather than interest from Manchester United.

The Newcastle midfielder was on the summer shortlist at Old Trafford but a £50million asking price meant a deal was always unlikely, especially given the 21-year-old had only played eight times in the Premier League.

Longstaff was also recovering from knee-ligament damage and his form this season under Bruce has been nowhere near the standard he set last term.

Steve Bruce says Sean Longstaff must focus on his displays rather than other clubs' interest

And the head coach was dismissive of the United link ahead of his former club's visit to St James' Park this afternoon.

'I think Sean Longstaff now needs to concentrate on his own performances, rather than worrying about speculation and tittle-tattle,' said Bruce.

'I don't think there was any real legs in the Man United story, it all happened before I arrived here.

'All Sean can do now is recover from his bad knee and start putting in the performances that would ultimately get you linked - and start playing well again.'

Bruce added: 'You are a young lad, you are going to be (distracted by the interest)'

Longstaff has admitted the interest was a distraction, and Bruce added: 'You are a young lad, you are going to be (distracted). He's got to learn to put that aside and just get on with the job in hand, which is playing for us.'

Longstaff wants a new deal at Newcastle as reward for his first-team breakthrough, which came just weeks after signing a new contract.

And Bruce said: 'I do believe he signed a new contract last Christmas. There is no problem there contract wise.

'The thing for him now is to forget contracts, forget his knee injury, forget Man Utd, it's all about playing well for us now and getting back to playing like we know he is capable.'
description: The Newcastle midfielder was on the summer shortlist at Old Trafford but a £50million asking price meant a deal was always unlikely and he was also recovering from knee ligament damage.
authors: Craig Hope For The Mail On Sunday
